response.answer_text: Wisdom is a virtue that isn’t innate, but can only be acquired through experience. Anyone who is interested in trying new things and reflecting on the process has the ability to gain wisdom. By learning as much as you can, analyzing your experiences and putting your knowledge to the test, you can become a wiser person. Part One of Three: Gaining Experience Edit 1 Try new things. It's hard to gain wisdom when you stay in and do the same thing day after day. You get wiser when you put yourself out there and give yourself the opportunity to learn, make mistakes and reflect on the experience. If you tend to be on the inhibited side, work on cultivating an inquisitive spirit and the willingness to put yourself in new situations.[1] Every time you experience something new, you open yourself up to the possibility of learning and getting a little wiser for having tried it. Going to places you've never been before is a great way to get some life experience. Such as booking a trip to another city, or taking a road trip to the next town over. Make an effort to eat at a restaurant that's popular with the locals, rather than going to your favorite chain. Every chance you get, choose newness over the familiar. Trying new social activities is another good way to open up your world. If you tend to spend your time watching sports, get tickets to see a play. If you're a total bookworm, you could sign up for a hiking club or join a bowling team. 2 Step out of your comfort zone. If you’re afraid to do something, perhaps that’s the very thing you should try to do. When you have to deal with an awkward or scary situation, you come out on the other side better equipped to handle fear the next time you face it. As Eleanor Roosevelt said, “We gain strength, and courage, and confidence by each experience in which we really stop to look fear in the face . . . we must do that which we think we cannot.” For example, if you’re afraid of public speaking, volunteer to give a presentation. If you dislike talking about your feelings, make an effort to have a conversation with a loved one telling the person how much you care. Ask the person how he or she feels, too. 3 Make an effort to talk to people you don’t know very well. Talk to people from different backgrounds and with different perspectives from yours, and pay attention to what you can learn from them. Try not to judge them based on your own narrow point of view. The more you're able to empathize with others, the wiser you will be.[2] Practice being a good listener, and ask a lot of questions to find out more. Really pay attention to what people are saying instead of letting your mind wander. Every conversation gives you the chance to understand someone better, broaden your views and thus become wiser. Share yourself with the people you're talking to, too. Work on going deeper than casual conversation and fostering new friendships. 4 Be open-minded. Instead of judging things you don’t know much about, consider them from every angle and make an effort to understand.[3] It's easy to base our views on the limited experiences we've had in life, but that's not the way to gain wisdom. You can't help that you've grown up in a certain place with certain people, but you can decide how open you are to learning about different ways of life. Don’t base your opinions of things on what other people think, or whether something is popular. Do your own research and look at both sides of the story before you decide what you think about something. For example, maybe you think a certain type of music isn’t cool because none of your friends like it. Before you jump on the bandwagon, try seeing a band play the music live, and read up on its history. When you've taken time to understand something, you can decide you don't like it, but not before then. A famous philosopher has been teaching his students about politics and ethics for years. His students dislike him, since he constantly belittles their intellect and brags about his. One day, a young girl musters up the courage in class to ask him a simple question: “How does one gain wisdom?” This catches the philosopher off-guard. He doesn’t know what to say and tries to explain that he doesn’t know the answer to her question, since he focuses on ethics and political philosophy, and not epistemology. The girl is surprised, “You brag about how smart you are and how dumb we are, but you can’t answer the simple question of how one gains wisdom?!!” The class bursts into laughter.  The next day, the philosopher confronts the girl, “The only reason I couldn’t answer your question yesterday was because I didn’t have time to think about it, otherwise the answer is simple: You gain wisdom from introspection. In fact, this is the only way to gain wisdom.” The girl smirks, “Are you sure? If we can only gain wisdom by thinking on our own, then why are we taking classes from you?” The philosopher is speechless and the class starts to laugh at him again.  A humbled philosopher comes to class the next day and addresses the girl, “I apologize for having been so arrogant over the years. I hope you can forgive me. You have taught me an important lesson: You can gain wisdom from others. ” The girl is pleased but decides to gloat, “You are a fool. I know far more than you ever did and should be teaching this class, since there is nothing more you can teach me.” The philosopher sees his opening, “Really? I was about to teach a third way to gain wisdom that neither of us has mentioned. But I guess you can tell us.” The girl regrets her boast, “I can’t…” Her classmates snicker. After an embarrassingly long pause she asks, “What is it?” “You can gain wisdom from experience. The experience of being embarrassed in front of this class for boastfulness has taught me humility. I hope it teaches the same to you too.”  Confucius has said “By three methods we may learn wisdom: First, by reflection, which is noblest; Second, by imitation, which is easiest; and third by experience, which is the bitterest.” There are other ways to gain wisdom too, but I think these three are a good start.

Wisdom is not gained, but uncovered! Our wisdom is a certain process of our mind! Dig deep within: Wisdom is secretly hidden in our minds just like a wealth of pot is hidden in our backyard. This pot of wealth was hidden by our grandfather in the backyard just to test whether we will take the pains to dig it our or not. We need not do anything to create it as it is already there. All we have to do is to dig ourselves deep within! Improving wisdom is what we do less with the senses and more with the sensibility! Being critical of the world is an obstacle to wisdom: If we gain false buoyancy by criticizing others, we can be sure of distancing ourselves from wisdom. Blaming others for our problems engages us in a vicious circle which traps us into a cauldron of anxiety and stress. They are self-sabotaged and there is no time in them for wisdom. Therefore, the first enemy of wisdom is criticising others. If criticising others were to create a sense of ‘feel-good’ factor within you, take it for granted that you are not a person of wisdom. The next enemy of wisdom is: Worrying about the future: Did you know I said this in my TEDx talk, “yesterday is but a rejected cheque, tomorrow is a promissory note and today is cash” There is a lot of difference between ‘being terrified of the future’ and ‘taking reasonable steps to reduce the uncertainty of the future’. The fear of the future is the worst nightmare of a person who thinks that he can rectify the future by just thinking. Thinking is a subtle phenomenon and the physical world is a solid operational world. We can never bring them together. However, we can equate them when we go beyond the physicality of sensory perception. This is the where wisdom dawns! Wisdom never lies in routine! Many people think that by cheating others they can make a profit and that is wisdom. They are thoroughly mistaken. Wisdom is that state where it should give us peace and tranquillity amidst adversity! A man who has made money by cheating or evading tax will not have peace of mind when tax authorities raid him. He will lose all his peace of mind if his whole family succumbs to Coronavirus. Whatever you are doing now using this physical body for this physical body and its security and enjoyment by employing illegal, immoral, unsocial, and dishonest means is not wisdom at all. Why is this not wisdom? Wisdom always gives permanent results and not impermanent. Whatever wealth they earned by illegal means just evaporated because of submicroscopic protein molecule which has no connection with their wealth, how can we take such wealth as permanent? When it is not permanent, how can that be an act of wisdom? I am a man of wisdom! I think I am a man of wisdom. I left a lucrative position which would have given me millions of dollars and joined an organization where I can educate people. Whatever little I have is sufficient for my life and I never beg from others. I continue to be happy. How about a person who lost billions in these days? Can they be happy? Therefore, wisdom is something that is not connected with our routine living but which deals with something beyond the routine. Future is uncertain: The future created by the material world of money is an illusion of uncertainty. People of wisdom understand that life is inherently uncertain. They face up to this uncertain world with a certain clarity that the ‘world in which we live including this physical body is uncertain’. They accept the path of acceptance rather than denial. I am promoting the principle of ‘ACT’ during this Covid19 time. A- Acceptance C- Commitment T- Therapy People of wisdom accept that the world is uncertain and later they take up only those undertakings which stabilize their accepted principle and this is their commitment. This serves as a therapy for the ailment of stress, and anxiety. They know that worry drains our today's strength and make us incapable of facing tomorrows adversity. The past is a rejected cheque! People of wisdom understand this. They never ruminate on past mistakes. They take past mistakes as experiences which have taught them lessons. They forget the past as easily as we have forgotten our childhood, diseased mother/father/spouse. We can forget these things easily but we cannot forget the harm done by an enemy. People of wisdom move on and they don’t allow the past to hurt their future journey. One thing is sure, the past can never be corrected or recalled. It is done. People of wisdom focus on the time which is becoming so fast, the past! There is no way of holding the water of a flowing river. You should flow with it. Human being has a weakness of sticking to the routine! This is the greatest built-in weakness of the human being. Whatever it is, he/she gets inured to it and wants the same thing to continue. He is the lover of routine. He wants to get up at the right time, have breakfast at the same time, everything should go as he wants it to happen. If everything were to go smoothly without any change, a human being would not have even died because no one wants to die. A man of wisdom knows that the world is a play and there should be surprises, otherwise, the whole show becomes a flop. Do you watch a movie which does not have a twist and turn? Ordinary people think too much while men of wisdom think little! Those who daydream are fools and those who enjoy the present moment are people of wisdom. Most of us daydream. All most all of us have unrealistic expectations. We suddenly want to become a billionaire or a movie icon. If you are not a person with good looks and have no acting talent, you cannot have an illusion of becoming a hero. It soon becomes a disillusion. A man of wisdom enjoys what he knows best. If he is a musician, he wants to learn more and more rather than making money out of that. The money may come as a byproduct. Men of wisdom never lose hope but have no expectations. Whatever that comes their way, they enjoy. They know that it is of no use to wear goggles when they are blind; no use of shoes when they are lame; no use of earphones when they are deaf; they know that if they leave this moment unenjoyed with all the organs of the body working, they will be committing an astronomical blunder! A wise old woman who was traveling in the mountains found a precious stone in a stream. The next day she met another traveler who was hungry, and the wise woman opened her bag to share her food. The hungry traveler saw the precious stone in her bag and wondered what an old woman would do with a precious stone. So, he asked the woman to give it to him. To his amazement, the wise woman said, “take it, I don’t need it”, and gave him the stone without hesitation. The traveler left, excited and rejoicing for his good fortune, which he had obtained without any struggle. He knew the stone was worth a fortune to give him enough security for the rest of his life. He realized he would never have to struggle for food, money or shelter, ever again. However, only a few days later, he came back to return the stone to the surprise of the wise old woman. “I’ve been thinking,” he said, “I know how valuable the stone is, but I want to give it back in the hope that you can give me something even more precious. Give me what you have within you that enabled you to give me something as precious as this stone.” “What you did was wise”, said the wise old woman. “You used your brain correctly and quickly realized that this stone is worthless unless your brain is valuable.” So, the wise old woman sat down the man and began to teach him everything she knew about wisdom: To acquire wisdom, you MUST commit yourself to a process of learning and applying what you’ve learned. The process takes a long, protracted time of discomfort, pain and struggle.Examine yourself first. You may already posses many traits or qualities of wisdom within you. Don’t just dismiss everything you have or everything life has taught you, including the struggles life has put you through. 20% of it is valuable, but 80% of it is junk.You must be wiling to go through the school of life and be willing to practice patience, persistence and endurance. I can’t promise you it’s going to be easy, but with the right mindset, coupled with the desire to acquire something more precious than gold, or precious stones, you can get there.There’s no set timeline or duration for learning wisdom, and there’s no measurement of wisdom. IT is a continuous process that involves lifelong learning. Wisdom gained fast will soon be forgotten and die. People who gain wisdom fast will die without it.First, you must kill all forms of fear, and develop a thick skin for failure, ridicule, risk, people’s jealousy, slander, bullying, persecution, and everything related with pride. Instead embrace humility.People will hurt you, and you will feel much pain. But this is nothing compared to how you will destroy yourself if you don’t learn to forgive, and control anger and bitterness.Most people have no time for wisdom and will do anything to avoid it. In fact, many people would rather die without it, because most people love life’s shortcuts.Wisdom is acquired through years of struggle, mistakes, and errors. Schools teach you to avoid mistakes. Life teaches you to make mistakes so that you can increase wisdom by discovering why you made mistakes and errors. The more you learn, the less the struggles, therefore, the less the mistakes.I’m not teaching you to go out there and look for mistakes and failure. I’m teaching you to prepare for them because life is full of them. However, I’m teaching you to learn from them if they occur.Every so often, find a quiet place. Alone. No mobile phones, no internet, no computers, and no television. Away from all the noise. Away from the office, away from the crowds and away from everything. Just quite, clean air and nature. Take this opportunity to empty yourself of all knowledge and life’s frustrations. At least for the moment. How do you feel? Now, take a deep breath and savour the fresh clean air. Ask yourself—”what I’m I doing wrong or right?” Start questioning everything. Then start from a clean slate—A clean canvas. Detoxify your brain of all garbage.Wisdom is not knowledge. In fact, wisdom is contrary to knowledge, for you don’t require an education to acquire it, but you require an open mind, determination and common sense to gain it.Grab a book of wisdom and read it as if your life depended on it. For example, you can start by reading the book of Proverbs in the bible, written by the wisest man who ever lived. Don’t worry if you’re not religious. Although it’s found in the bible, it’s not a religious book. Kings have read it. Non-religious people have read it, and acquired more wisdom to protect their kingdoms, their wealth, their lives, and their families.You will not become wise overnight or by reading wisdom books alone. But you will become wise through persistence and experience, and by practicing what wisdom books say.Learn to be polite and kind. Learn to share, and learn to help. You don’t acquire wisdom by grabbing and accumulating everything to yourself. You gain wisdom by sharing the little you have with others who don’t have anything.Learn the art of listening and acknowledge that you don’t know everything. In fact, the listener gains more than the speaker, and the speaker loses more than the listener. Socrates said it all when he said, “This much I know-I know nothing…”Although wisdom is invisible, the impact of wisdom is visible. Although wisdom is sometimes acquired through trial and error, once acquired, the trials and errors will decrease significantly as you become wiser.Wisdom is more important than gold, diamonds or any precious stones. It gives you the power to acquire anything you want, but more importantly, it gives you the power to control greed and avoid danger. The right question, well formed and asked with clear intention, will point you in the right direction. There is an art to master here. When you master the art of asking the right questions you’re more than halfway there to finding your best answers. I was halfway through a coaching session with a new coaching client when she blurted out, ‘You scare me.’ As the session progressed and we explored her statement together it became clear that what was scaring her was not in fact me (I’m harmless really – I promised) but the questions being pitched her way. One of the first things you will learn to do as your won best life coach is how to ask yourself the right questions and to coach yourself into a habit of self questioning on a regular basis. You’ll be developing questions that both put you in touch with what you really want and help in finding the best possible ways of achieving this. Powerful questions not only change the way you think but also the choices and actions you make. You know when you’ve hit upon one of those questions when you think, ‘Oh I hadn’t thought about it like that,’ or ‘That’s a good question,’ or words or thoughts to that effect. Questions can be used to generate new possibilities and challenge old ways of thinking and behaviors, as well as validating and encouraging progress. But be prepared that when you ask the questions you’re ready to listen to and take on board the answers. To keep tabs on the kinds of questions you ask, use the following checklist as a form of accountability to ensure your questions are taking you in the right direction. Will making this choice take me towards what I truly want or will it keep me stuck in my past?Am I pleasing myself or trying to please others? Does thinking about taking this action make me feel energised or do I feel drained?Will this habit or action give me short-term gratification or will I gain longer-lasting satisfaction?Am I focusing on the solution or on the problem?Are my thoughts right now self-nurturing and affirming or self-attacking or critical?Will this habit or action empower me or disempower me?Like this? Here are a few different methods by which wisdom can be acquired: Reading — lots of it — of high-quality content. Usually, this would be in the form of favorably-reviewed books, well-respected newspapers and magazines, and their on-line/electronic-format equivalents. Blogs and discussion forums can also provide occasional nuggets of wisdom, but these sources require extra discernment and filtering to extract the useful content from the vast oceans of useless drivel which often dominate.Life experience — lots of it — often in the form of learning hard lessons from failures. This means avoiding the repetition of mistakes, and also includes the repeating (and refining) of successes. Become well-practiced in your skills and successful behavior patterns so that they become second-nature. Also, be willing to take some risks (calculated risks, not reckless risks). In most cases, your risk tolerance will decrease with age (since you have more to lose, and less time remaining to recover from losses), so take your biggest risks while still young.From others wiser than yourself — parents, grandparents, older siblings, teachers, mentors, leaders/pillars of the community, those who have earned high rank/status within an organization. Occasionally, though, one can discover nuggets of wisdom from someone much younger, even from a child. Some people can be surprisingly wise beyond their age, and if such wisdom manifests itself visibly, then by all means learn from it. Or, sometimes a child is simply “being a child”, but the child’s words and/or behavior in a specific situation may somehow serve as a catalyst to “gel together” some not yet internalized components of wisdom acquired earlier and elsewhere.From meditation, self-reflection, internalization of the elements of wisdom gained from external sources. This doesn’t necessarily mean sitting on the floor in a lotus position with palms together in a prayer-like pose, although one can certainly do this if it’s helpful. The important thing is to carefully organize the thoughts/ideas and try to codify/formulate them into simple, easy-to-follow rules and constructive patterns of behavior. One way to do this effectively is to sit down at a computer and type it into a personal diary entry or blog article. Or, if it works better, just use paper and a pen or pencil, which has the advantage of free-form and drawing of pictures. Perhaps a combination of all of these methods would work best.From a genuine humbleness of attitude, not just expressed externally but also felt internally. The more one learns, the more one realizes just how vast the world (and universe) is, and how very tiny one’s own knowledge/wisdom is, compared to what is actually knowable. Humbleness should be practiced as quietly and subtly as possible (don’t make any efforts to draw attention to it). There is a thing called “humble-bragging”, and a truly wise person would want to avoid engaging in it.Finally, the gaining of wisdom is an ongoing process. There should never be any moment in which one truly believes: “Wisdom acquired — mission accomplished! Moving on to something else…”

One can gain wisdom by asking right questions. This story of two brothers will show you ‘how’.  (Image Source : Business Insider)[1] Brothers who cofounded a $100 million company say this question their mom asked every night at dinner is what inspired their business. Bert and John Jacobs, the brothers who cofounded the $100 million Life Is Good T-shirt company, grew up the youngest of six children in a lower middle-class family in Boston. When the brothers were in elementary school, their parents were in a near-death car accident from which their mother managed to escape with just a few broken bones — but their father lost the use of his right hand. The stress and frustration from his physical therapy caused him to develop a harsh temper. "He did a lot of yelling when we were in grade school," John writes in his new book ‘Life Is Good.’. And life certainly wasn't perfect. "There were often difficult things happening around the house," the brothers write. But their mom, Joan, still believed life was good. So, every night as the family sat around the dinner table, she would ask her six kids to tell her something good that happened that day. As simple as mom's words were, they changed the energy in the room. Before we knew it, we were all riffing on the best, funniest, or most bizarre part of our day. John says that this daily exercise prevented them from developing a victim's mentality of "Oh, you wouldn't believe this horrible thing that happened to me today." Instead of griping about a teacher or homework assignment, he says that they would be laughing about a silly haircut a classmate got that day, or a neat project they worked on at school. That optimism was something that our family always had, even when we had little else. Growing up with a mother like theirs — one who sang in the kitchen, told animated stories, and acted out children's books for them, no matter what bad situation they were going through — taught them an important lesson: Being happy isn't dependent on your circumstances. She showed us that optimism is a courageous choice you can make every day, especially in the face of adversity. They say her unwavering positive outlook on life is what inspired Life Is Good — their $100 million company the mission of which is to spread the power of optimism, with the tagline, "Life is not perfect. Life is not easy. Life is good." Since their mother's daily question served them so well in life, John says he and his brother now ask their employees the same thing when they all come together — "Tell me something good" — and the results have been positive. He explains, It leads to ideas, which lead to progress, which leads to building on successes, instead of dwelling on challenges. This nightly routine of asking “tell me something good” went a long way. “It is not the answer that enlightens, but the question.” – Eugene Ionesco Footnotes[1] Brothers who cofounded a $100 million company say a question their mom asked every night at dinner inspired their business

I'm going to write something that disagrees with the dictionary definition of wisdom a bit. It may be my own working definition rather than anything traditional. Wisdom is not (despite what Socrates is alleged to have felt) knowledge ABOUT any particular thing. It is not a scholastic study, a body of learning nor a technique. A person may know a lot about individual things and still be lacking in wisdom. They can be one of the world's great experts in a field or even several fields and still lack wisdom.  It would be difficult to display wisdom if you knew nothing at all about particular things but that isn't wisdom. Knowledge is not intelligence: there are very clever people who are damn fools.  What I mean by wisdom is the ability to put the things you know into context. To relate the things you know to each other and to the world in which that knowledge has its existence. To know how to judge the claims of economic development against those of environmental risk and those of cultural change would require wisdom.  Wisdom is seeing the big picture. We never, ever get enough wisdom to see the whole picture: perfect wisdom isn't within human achievement. But we can work on it.  How you gain it is more complex. Some people seem to have it naturally in some areas, most of us have to work on it all our lives.  There are prerequisites. Humility is one, the admission that your own viewpoint is necessarily limited. That implies you need to be able to admit that you have been wrong and to listen to people you disagree with. A willingness to go on learning your whole life long.  Part of the core of wisdom is prudence, which I often describe as a sort of 'weaponised cowardice'. Being aware of the things that can go wrong is a defence against enthusiasm.  But courage also part of wisdom: the willingness to take chances and hope for a better future.  As to how you acquire it: practice, practice, practice. Always try to see how what you know fits in with other things and what you have just learned fits in with what you already know.

When one is to leave the gym after intensive training, they do not gain muscle in their rest; the muscles already exist inside their bodies. All they do is to expand in accordance to the stimulation they were given. No new muscles are added, as they only grow. The same goes for wisdom. We all contain different potentials at various of degrees. All we need for their development is specific stimulation that will trigger their blossom; each stimulation to each potential. Muscles can be gained either by external stimulation (lifting weights, for example), or through self-sufficient stimulation (doing push ups, stretching, so forth). The same goes for wisdom as said before. Interact with wisdom-developing stimulations, or challenge yourself through the Art of Philosophizing, and the seeds within you shall gradually grow. Wisdom can be gained through every possible thing, since wisdom feeds on knowledge, and everything is knowledge, everything is information. Whether real or false, physical or illusion, everything in existence and non-existence is of information that can be used for the construction of wisdom. Wisdom is the optimal execution of knowledge, regardless of what is the nature of the said knowledge. Every fruit you may find on your journey could be used as a potentially healthy and tasty salad. Either collect or create knowledge through interactions (externally), contemplations (internally), or through the combination of them. Remember that the same station can be reached through various of ways, and thus there it is not necessary to reach a state through all the possible ways. Make sure you are to rest after an intensive sessions, and don’t exhaust yourself, or else the muscle will not only stop to grow but might also deteriorate and minimize itself. The same applies goes for wisdom. I myself need, at times, complete days to distract and entertain myself, so my mental energies required for philosophizing shall recharge. Therefore there is no shame in killing time, if that time serves for recharging oneself for ultimately be productive and efficient. Thanks to BRandon IOI for requesting my wisdom.

Good question! One philosophers have been thinking about for centuries. There is no one set formula for gaining wisdom but in my experience I have found that several factors can help: Interact with different people: Don’t simply associate with people who are just like you and think just like you. Interacting with people from different walks of life and people who have different ideas about life than you do (in religion and politics for example) will provide you with some interesting insights about the world. Spend time in nature: Thinkers like Emerson and Thoreau recognized the value of nature in coming to a deep understanding about life. Read Walden and spend some time in the woods! Meditate: This technique has been around for centuries. It is good for cultivating mindfullness and can potentially lead to other deep insights about yourself and the world. Make connections among different subjects: Wisdom comes, in part, from the recognition of the deep interconnectedness of things: people, places, history, ideas, and life. So, start looking for those connections in what you learn and experience. Travel: Finally, a good way to enhance your perspective on life is to travel. See different people, places, and sights and you will gain a “worldly” perspective which will help you cultivation of wisdom. Read good books: Both fiction and non-fiction provide a rich source of wisdom that you can use for insight. In particular, great books which have withstood the test of time are some of the best sources for wisdom. Consider reading some great works of literature as well as works of philosophy and history. Here’s a few suggestions: How Should We Live? Great Ideas from the Past for Everyday Life by Roman Krznaric Walden or Life in the Woods by Henry David Thoreau Nichomachean Ethics by Aristotle 30 Lessons for Living: Tried and True Advice from the Wisest Americans by Karl Pillemer 29 Gifts: How a Month of Giving Can Change Your Life by Cami Walker The Spiritual Teachings of Ralph Waldo Emerson by Richard Geldard Obliquity: Why our goals are best achieved indirectly by John Kay

At the time of Heraclitus, a student of Pythagoras (~535-475 BCE) so-called "wisdom poetry" was already thousands of years old.   Heraclitus, who would concur with Einstein that energy is the essence of matter, also said:  "All things change to fire and fire exhausted falls back into things."  Einstein used mathematical language E=MC2 to say it and this was later confirmed by scientific experience.  This might lead one to conclude that Heraclitus was wise beyond his age (all things considered). Here are some of the (translated) passages from Heraculitus that survived time. "Wisdom is the oneness of mind that guides and permeates all things" "Applicants for Wisdom, do what I have done; inquire within." I might just comment, before the rest of these selected quotes, that first thing you will need is a strong dose of humility.  You have to reach deep into your psyche for this.  It only comes from within yourself.  Getting at it is in no way easy or graceful; on the contrary it is excruciating.  Most fail.  You must be mindful that the search is a process and wisdom is an objective (the idea) and you must search for it in order to get to know it; to grasp a measure for yourself. "The habit of knowledge is not human, but divine." "Yet, let's not make rash guesses our most lucid thoughts." "The harmony past knowing sounds more deeply than the known" Form this habit by getting into the habit of being thankful, gracious and just being the mindful instrument that you are.  Keep an even, open mind; don't be superficial.  Be mindful.  Recognize. Discern; think deeply. Strengthen your habit in the silence of meditation, contemplation and supplication (if only to stay your tongue) and realize it in thankfulness and gratefulness.  Don't substitute or satiate your objective for your silly preferences. "Seekers of Wisdom first need sound intelligence." "While Cosmic Wisdom understands all things are good and just, intelligence may find injustice here and justice somewhere else." "To be even-minded is the greatest virtue." "Since mindfulness, of all things, is the ground of all being, to speak one's true mind and to keep things known in common, serves all being, just as laws made clear, uphold the city. "Of all the pronouncements of the law, the one source is the word whereby we choose what helps true mindfulness prevail". (word=logos)  "The word proves those first hearing it as numb to the understanding as the one’s who have not heard. Yet all things follow from the word." Additional comments: In the beginning was the Word.”  In this diction, in the Gospel according to John, he must have had Heraclitean thought in mind.  The Logos induces not only the lexical word or terms of reference, but also all means of making known, as well as its objectives; the phenomena to which ideas respond, and the rules that govern both phenomena and ideas.    When people hear and use words these days, it is through their ordinary language where words are supposed to be arbitrary labels of things.  The means of making known is taken for granted; the objective is forgotten or superseded by the latest fad or what the celebrity said.  Many don't even suspect that mental and behavioral phenomena respond to ideas and virtually no one recalls or remembers the rules that govern both. In short, what was at one time, common sense, is not so common anymore.  Yet, as Heraculitus also said: "From the strain of binding opposites comes harmony."

This is a very important question. Perhaps the most important question in the universe. But of course, I could be wrong. I don’t know if I can answer this question satisfactorily, but I am willing to try if you are willing to bear with me. As I understand it, wisdom is the combination of intelligence and knowledge with the intention of applying it for good, ethical and righteous (not self-righteous) purposes. Intelligence is something we are all born with to varying degrees, but is not static - i.e it is not entirely dependent on genetic precursors; it can be expanded and improved upon through mental exercise (similar to working out in the gym to build physical muscle). Knowledge is something we each must work for through various means. Education is not achieved exclusively through the education system - school, college, university - it is a process of self-directed-learning as part of a personally developed ‘discovery-enriched curriculum’. In the modern age we live in, where information is readily available through the internet or the public library, this is surely not beyond the reach of anyone who is passionate about knowledge. In the search for knowledge, I can recommend a good place to begin - that is the science of Human Temperament. Personally I subscribe to the original system of temperament classification laid down by Hippocrates (around 450BC) - based on the Four Humors, otherwise known as the four body fluids - phlegm (Phlegmatic), blood (Sanguine), bile from liver (Choleric) and bile from kidneys (Melancholy). The link is Four classic temperaments and spirituality. I prefer the Hippocratic system because it is easily disseminated/shared and you don’t have to be a psychologist to understand the principles and put them into practice. By this process of understanding the temperaments we gain a deeper understanding of ourselves and the other people around us. Therefore we progress in our evolutionary development. But of course we need to be aware that ‘nobody fits into a box’ and I prefer to think of people as “maybe this AND this AND that” rather than “this OR that”. Temperamental traits are inherited largely through our grandparents and more distant ancestors (often the traits of our parents tend to skip a generation or even two), and we may inherit traits or characteristics of further-removed ancestors from two, three, or even four of the four main temperament classes. Hence, a person’s temperamental makeup is diverse and complex, but understandable given time, observation and interest. Naturally, for a student of temperament theory who has achieved the state of Unconscious Competence, the process of ‘diagnosing’ the temperamental makeup of ‘others’ is less time-consuming as they are more likely to ‘sense’ a person’s predominant temperament through an intuitive process borne of long experience and expertise, or even to detect a sense of ‘chemistry’ when encountering another person, especially if the other person has a similar temperamental makeup to the observer (like attracts like and opposites repel). This has been my experience since I started this journey twenty years ago, however one must never become complacent or judgmental by ignoring the need for observation and analysis before attempting to construct a working hypothesis. As for the idea of ‘personality’ and its construction, this is a discussion for another day as it includes many factors - with temperament as the foundation, but also the influences of culture, religion, politics, family background, perceived economic and social status, and many other considerations including the notion of ‘personal choice’ when it comes to a person’s personality and personal identity. Naturally, a person can only make an informed ‘choice’ about their personality and who they want to be, if they have the necessary knowledge to inform that choice. The acquisition of knowledge is not an easy process but our confidence is further helped along by an understanding of Competence Theory. According to this theory, we progress through various stages of competence until we reach the final stage where we are competent without needing to think about it – i.e the knowledge has been mastered and becomes a matter of instinct and intuition. For example, when we are children and we first learn to ride a bicycle, or as young adults learning to drive a car for the first time. We begin in the state of Unconscious Incompetence (we don’t know that we don’t know or how much we don’t know). From there we work at it and reach the stage of Conscious Incompetence (We start to find out what we don’t know, how much we don’t know, and what it is that we need to know). The next leg of the journey is Conscious Competence, as we practice more and become good at what we do provided we concentrate and focus our attention on the task at hand. The final stage is that of Unconscious Competence – where we simply jump on our bicycle and go for a ride without thinking about the process of what to do first, how to maintain balance or how to use gears etc. In driving a car at this stage you may have your mind on other matters and suddenly find yourself having arrived at the destination with no clear memory of the journey. Some folks arrive at the stage of Unconscious Competence faster than others, depending on temperamental makeup, mental acuity through discipline, and other factors including physiological and mental health. There is much that can be done to accelerate the process. So wisdom is about combining intelligence and wisdom to do good. But how do we know what is good? There are various philosophical discourses about Ethics. Utilitarianism seems to be the dominant system in terms of governmentality as it generally aims to achieve ‘the greatest good for the greatest number of people’ (and never mind about those marginalised minority individuals who ‘fall through the cracks’). I am partial to Ethics of care and Ethics of Virtue, however my main focus has always been on the notion of ‘sustainability’ in that the ethical standards must be safe for everyone to practice without having any harmful effect to the local community or the broader society in general. For example, before I commit a certain act I tend to ask myself “what would happen if everyone were to do the same as me?” (my basis starts with Kant’s theory of Deontology). I recall an incident in my childhood where a friend challenged me to steal a bottle of Coca Cola from our neighbourhood corner store. We knew that the shopkeeper was out the back doing stocktake, and the chance of getting caught was slim, but I refused the challenge because I realised that my action could encourage others to do the same, and perhaps more expensive items would go ‘missing’ which over time may cause the shop owner to go bankrupt and close the store. I did not refuse because I was afraid of getting caught, that my parents and the Police would punish me and I would be made to feel bad (these are wrong reasons to CTR (Choose The Right). I refused because I was afraid the shop would close due to the ‘snowball’ effect which I had started, and then the entire neighbourhood would be disadvantaged without the convenience of a corner store. I also considered the impact on the shop owner and his family, as he my have faced financial hardship and ruin, thereby denying his children the chance to attend college or university. Even from a young age, I was intuitively aware of the importance of this notion of ‘sustainability’. Such ideas should be taught to children from the time they start at Kindergarten, and then on through Primary School (Elementary school for our American friends), onto high school, college and university. I hope I have at least partially answered the question of “how does one truly gain wisdom”. The only other remark I can make is that in my opinion wisdom is borne of disciplined thinking and ethical choices. To achieve true wisdom we must firstly arrive at a state of ‘higher-evolved-consciousness’ through the pain and suffering of lived experience. In short, ‘growing pains’ or ‘teething pains’ cannot be avoided unless we want to stop growing or stop teething. This is how humans learn. In my personal opinion, Quora is a wonderful repository of knowledge, and I am passionate in my conviction that knowledge should always be shared freely and free of charge as we try to help each other long the path of life as we know it on this planet.

How To Crack Your Inner Wisdom:  Do you ever feel like you trust your gut almost to a 100%, but your heart and your mind are not on the same page? Sometimes the decisions you would like to make become a dragged out dilemma to the point of debilitation. It is a tough sentiment to get through, believe me. You are not alone. This is a problem that plagues a lot of people from achieving their full potential. The problems start when we listen too much to outside noises and believing that those voices have a point. We start to think that we are doing it wrong. The reason for it is due to a basic lack of self-esteem and confidence to say that: NO! YOU are the one that is doing it wrong. On a personal level, this had defined my teens through school and even into my early 20s and I felt I was a prisoner in my own mind only to develop the proper mental frame and mechanism. Ever since the decision to target these mental games, my personal and mental development has been light years of a difference for myself. Self-esteem is at an all time high and I feel more than 150% confident about whom I am as an individual. It is such a powerful feeling. It really is all mental — the mind is a powerful tool and a powerful weapon. We ultimately have the power to change it. It really is in our hands and a simple honest talk with yourself every day could go a long way. What is Inner Wisdom/Voice? It is a tool for quick and ready insight. It is a gut feeling, a 6th sense, an inner knowing. It is almost instinctual. It is a feeling of that particular situation “feeling right”. It is an unexplainable feeling at times. Listening to ourselves can get tricky. Often our inner wisdom is a mere whisper. It is a murmur that is especially hard to hear over your harsh inner critic.​ Some of the readers may argue that sometimes that inner voice is the one that needs to be tamed and may be that inner voice is even stopping themselves from achieving great things due to fear of failure. The key? Map it out. This does not have to be serious. You can play and experiment and pivot to see what messages you get and may be logic could come into play to dictate. How to Listen to Your Inner Wisdom ​Let’s look at how to connect to your inner wisdom. 1. Calm down. When my mind is calm, the connection to my inner wisdom is the strongest. When my mind is in turmoil, I do not try to make any decisions, but to let it subside and to just let it go! I let my mind run wild through many scenarios freely, until the calmness approaches and it does, because the mind is a muscle and that muscle will get tired. Sometimes and unfortunately, negativity comes into the picture. It is NORMAL to have your ups & downs. Remember you are human. It would be unnatural if it was otherwise. If I find myself in a negative state, I might go for a run, listen to powerful and inspirational music, immediately read inspirational short-stories, quotes and people or meditate. Personally, I do not try to suppress the negativity but really just take a break and to exhale.​ When you take a break, even for a minute or two to blink, gradually your calm will return along with the connection to your wisdom. 2. Stop Forcing It. I cannot stand it when I hear excuses about why something could not be done and even more so when I fall into that trap. I want to figure it all out. I want to force results, and I want to have achieved my goals last year. The more you force something, the more slowly things happen and sometimes they do not happen at all. This does not mean to be complacent. Not at all and to never ever further mean that persistence is useless. Persistence is VITAL to achieving your full potential. In everything you do from relationships to your workplace and all aspects of life. Fighting for what you want is the essence to connecting to your inner wisdom and the essence of success in general. “Stop Forcing it” means being aware of what you could control and what you do not. And it goes back to calming down. When you are worried about what might go wrong in life and you’re trying to fix an imaginary problem, the connection to your wisdom, mind and heart is detached. But once you learn to become aware that you do not know where life is going, you can relax and control the decisions that you make on that specific day and in that specific time. 3. Patience. My inner wisdom shines when I am patient. In the public eye, my patience is well understood. Behind the scenes, however, I have a fire that rages from within. I want to win and want to win now. I am competitive. I hate to lose. Sometimes to the point where I lose sleep over it and other times to the point where I grit my teeth. When you are in the weeds with something or grinding hard at work, sometimes we fail to see what the bigger picture is about. Understand what your “end goal” is. Again we do not know where life is going. It is scary to grasp. But its also beautiful. Take a step back and let your mind and heart dictate how you feel about a particular idea or situation. The more distance you give something, your inner wisdom shines. It takes time, but you will definitely know that feeling. Pitfalls The biggest pitfall I fall into over and over is stressing about whether or not I am on the right path. This “worry” has plagued me ever since I was 16 years old. I broke myself down to the core, went through a period of self-analysis and self-critique. I was brutal with myself and my own harshest critic throughout the happiest periods of people’s lives (a.k.a college). I felt like I was missing out on living and what was worse, I was comparing myself to others and that is the most self-defeating. Lessons Learned I am fortunate to have a very large circle of friends. I am even more fortunate to have a very close inner-circle. That inner-circle was the extreme opposite of myself. They were “free”. They believed that life will work itself out; to take it a day at a time and to let go of the tight self-imposed constraints. I have observed their attitudes and have molded and adapted it to my own personal characteristics. IT WAS SUCH A CONCEPT. I had the belief that if you did not stress about whether you are or not on the right path, then you just did not care. It was a false assumption to make. I have come to accept that life will take me where I need to go. I can only do my best with what I have and only so much I could control. Surround yourself with good people who have your best intentions at heart. Surround yourself with great friends. Most importantly, surround yourself with friends who have differing personalities and outlooks on life than you do. You could learn so much from them. What You Need to Remember I mapped out my life (my 20s to age 30) at the age of 16. I had it all laid out — from entering university at age 17 to finishing in 3 years (which I did), to being a multi-millionaire by the age of 25 to having my empire at the age of 30. I LOVED planning it out. It gave me joy. It made me feel like I cared more than anyone else about where I want to go. It is important to have goals. I always have goals. What people fall into (I, included) is attaching timelines to everything. This caused stress and anxiety if those timelines were not met. Let it go. Empirical experience will first and foremost be the main agent here. While logical training and education are also necessary, they’ll never really mean anything and you’ll never really internalize the significance or learn to use said knowledge unless it becomes salient through first-hand experience. I think a good place to begin would be to develop an actively adaptable and evolving personal manifesto to live by. Stoicism sets a good foundation because it teaches us to not let ourselves be bothered by what is outside of our control but also to take virtuous action when it is within our abilities to do so. This is in and of itself quite powerful, but it’s not quite that simple. In order to learn to determine what is within our control and what the right course of action to take is is where things get more complicated. To develop this skill will be an ongoing never ending journey involving putting yourself out there in the real world, taking on challenges, meeting new people and remaining open minded. This in addition to voracious reading will be a good place to begin. As someone who has studied philosophy both in university and on my own time, I love diving into widely varying schools of thought and trying to determine for myself what is true and what is right. Another benefit to studying different philosophies is that you’ll notice patterns and similarities between them and thereby can come closer to uncovering universal truths and values. For some people some of the more in depth post-modernistic teachings can seem a little like mental masturbation and maybe be unnervingly deconstructionist. For some it’s depressing and for others they simply wonder what the point is. I personally love reading the works of Derrida and Foucault as a challenge and as a means of furthering my ability to reason through problems, as they are incredibly insightful and rigorous thinkers. While I accept the fact that we can never be certain of anything (except perhaps consciousness) and that Moral objectivity doesn’t exist. I believe it is our ethical duty to try and come as close to moral objectivity as we can and to do our best to determine universal truths and values (to the best of our abilities). I believe my extensive background in stoicism allows me to look at it this way and is why I am unafraid of tackling any philosophical idea no matter how bleak or challenging it may seem. A lot of wisdom comes down to mindfulness which can be achieved through meditation and meditative activities as well as knowledge of logic and rationality, consider also keeping some sort of journal, blog or diary as means of there really is no substitute for writing as a means of organizing your thoughts and developing your ideas. Combine this with the empirical experiences of taking on knew challenges, making friends, travelling, relationships, growing older and I think you’re on the right track to wisdom.

Go to the source. Ask for it. It’s that simple.  What source? How shall such a request be made? Well, if there is such a thing as wisdom, and if such stuff is attainable, then it must be available via the world we live in. That is not to say it belongs to the universe we experience, but it does mean that it can be communicated through it. By analogy, Light is not the vacuum of space, but it can be transmitted by it. Indeed, ‘information’ is entirely meta-physical. There is no sense in which substances and their energies make sense of their substances and energies. Frequencies are not music. However, music is made of frequencies when such periods are provided with purpose. What is the purpose of the Universe? Is there one? If not, then everything is meaningless - and even the sentence ‘everything is meaningless’ communicates nothing. However, if there is an intentionality to what we experience as events in time then surely the medium through which such expression emerges can conduct conversation in more than one way? Phases can be inverted, after all. The really fascinating thing is that they can appear unchanged even where that occurs. That’s how things seem to stand…  With all this in mind, it is a habit of mine to do the following - hopefully each day. LORD, if it be your will, please grant me wisdom. Not for my glory, but for yours. Who am I referring to? I am using a name to invoke the Name Above All Names. That is ironic, to be sure. However, my own name depends merely on my recognition of it, not the user’s use. To some I am ‘doctor’, to others I am ‘Dave’, to one I am ‘daddy’. They are all the same person, and none of them captures the whole. Am I only speaking to emptiness? If so, then nothing is lost - and only some humility is learned. The practice teaches me that wisdom does not dwell in my own determinations - Everything is beyond me and it is my responsibility to reach out to it. If there is a source of all that is True, though, then my appeal to it constitutes the most basic of logical operations - a reference to an Axiom. In fact, one might call the inquiry above the most essential proof of meaningful existence.

I spend time with older, mature, experienced people in the field I am hoping to learn about. For example, as a clergyman, I gain my knowledge from books and personal study. I gain wisdom from spending time one-on-one with older, more experienced Christian men whose life experiences have taken them places I can only imagine. There are also areas of life outside my vocation. In no way am I mechanically inclined. To gain wisdom about my car and how it works, when I take it to the shop, I ask my mechanic about what he is doing, what is wrong, how I can avoid future problems, and about other projects he is working on. In this case, while he is not older, he is wiser than I am because he has been doing this work for over thirty years. Do not be proud in your search for wisdom. Be humble and willing to learn from any source available. I commend you in your desire to search for wisdom. It was the only thing that Solomon, the wisest man to ever live, asked God to grant him when he was told he could have anything he wished.

There’s a distinct difference between wisdom and knowledge. Your question was about wisdom, but I thought I’d draw a comparison for the sake of clarity. Knowledge is something your absorb from reading, lectures or discussions. Wisdom is only gained through personal experience. Life wisdom is gained when one takes the time to reflect on life experiences to detect behavior patterns, and shifts his behavior in a good way based on the learning he finds in those patterns. The more life experiences one accumulates, and the more time spent in reflection, the greater the wisdom. That’s why you’ve heard the term “wise elders” to refer to people who have been through a lot, and freely share their wisdom. Western society, unfortunately, doesn’t seem to put much stock in elder wisdom. By the time one reaches 50 he/she is often considered “over the hill”; has far fewer career opportunities available; and is sometimes ignored by his younger family. I’ve witnessed the effect of discreet age discrimination in Fortune 50 companies - they don’t want to run afoul of laws, yet they want to provide some upward mobility for their younger managers - so they offer a sweetheart buyout to older employees who have been excellent, loyal, consistent performers throughout their career. And in the process, cast off years of process or project wisdom for theoretical or academic knowledge. A bad trade. By comparison, in Asia it’s common to have 3 or 4 generations living under the same roof. Sometimes it’s financial, but it’s always seen as an example to expose the kids to their grandparents’ or great-grandparents’ wisdom. I’ve been called father or grandfather by strangers in Asia, as a show of respect. In some countries, younger people take the elder’s hand and put it to their forehead - a symbolic gesture to acknowledge and indicate a desire to absorb the elder’s wisdom. These are beautiful traditions that always feel wonderful to me. Namaste!

Wisdom comes primarily from our experience of life and relationships. Variety and breadth of experience matters less than actual involvement with people and situations over a significant period of time. Certainly some diversity of experience is important but passing through events like a 'sightseer' is of minimal value. It is as we involve ourselves in the messiness of life and its problems, including working with people and responding to them, that wisdom grows. This aspect of life is difficult and we have to learn to handle our own emotional responses so that, at the very least, we do not alienate others. As we involve ourselves with people and situations we are certain to make mistakes. Wisdom grows as we learn to be honest with ourselves and to reflect on how we can learn from failure so as to improve our practice or behaviour for the future. To a large degree this is a matter of growth in self-understanding, not just in a psychological sense but in terms of our strengths and weaknesses. Sometimes we need to do what we cannot currently do and self-knowledge can help us to make the necessary adjustments. Wisdom is related to knowledge, particularly in an area where we need some expertise. On a traditional view of wisdom, living a good life and flourishing as a human being is what we need to become expert in doing. In the modern world, specialist knowledge is needed for many employment situations. To begin with we have to learn the first principles which may not come easily, but through perseverance the knowledge we have gained forms into patterns in our mind, even if we are not entirely aware of that happening. This is the way that knowledge becomes part of us and as it does so we find the wisdom to think creatively in our area of expertise. To gain wisdom we have to be in it for the long haul. If that comes across as hard, all we need in practice is wisdom for tomorrow's problems. Most people have the wisdom they need for the stage of life they are in and if they do not have it there are usually people around who they can ask for advice. One traditional aspect of wisdom concerns the purpose or meaning of life and it is at least questionable whether we can become truly wise without reflecting on such matters, including life's spiritual meaning. According to the Bible, knowing the Creator God is central to wisdom because the qualities that we need in order to flourish are perfectly combined in God. According to the Bible, when we root our lives in God we grow in the quality of life that he represents, including in a wisdom which is essentially a matter of love.

The conventional wisdom is how things were done historically and how do you apply it to your current situation. Conventional wisdom allows the person to make adjustments based upon previous knowledge. And in a nutshell, that's the difference between gaining knowledge and having wisdom. So how do you gain knowledge to gain wisdom. The more you read and the more eclectic your reading is, at some point you will reach a critical mass of learning. This critical mass is the knowledge of the ages speaking through you as one. That's when the epiphany has occurred. Will this epiphany happen for everyone? And the answer is no! You can read every book that Einstein read and not be able to arrive at the prophetic conclusions that he arrived at. But even if you're stuck at the conventional wisdom level, you will be at a level few people ever arrive at. So read on and learn on! You'll be pleasantly surprised by the ride that you're on.

They worry about how they are perceived in a single moment, worry about things they can solve in a single day, and blame themselves for things that are long gone. Someone who has gained Wisdom, on the other hand, always has as connection to the bigger goal. They don’t worry about how they are perceived by people that do not matter to them, don’t even consider problems that they can instantly solve, and never blame themselves for things they cannot change. Wise Men and Women always have a connection to what really matters to them; which is exactly how you gain wisdom.  To gain more wisdom remind yourself of what really matters at all times. It’s not the pain in your muscles that matters but the exercise, health benefits and the muscle growth. It’s not the perceptions of other people that’s important but how you perceive and love yourself. It’s not about the money you make, but about the happiness you gain. Once you stop putting value in the wrong things you won’t be able to help becoming wiser. “I believe that all wisdom consists in caring immensely for a few right things, and not caring a straw about the rest.” - John Buchan Care about the things that really matter and put action behind each and every one of them. That is how you become wiser.

I like to preface my response to the thrust of your question with this elegant quote from well-known American industrialist Henry Ford: "Thinking is hard work, and that is why very few people engage in it." Thinking new ideas often will give us a new and broad perspective to look at the ever abundant data around us in order for us to gather valuable information for planning and decision making.  Always remember this, ideas must come first. Thomas Edison, the famous inventor, once remarked: "Make it a practice to keep on the lookout for novel and interesting ideas that others have used successfully.  Your idea has to be original only in its adaptation to the problems you are working." Robert Kiyosaski, author of ‘If You Want to Be Rich & Happy Don't Go to School: Ensuring Lifetime Security for Yourself and Your Children’, gave this simple advice to all those who wants to be rich: "It's what in your head that determines what is in your hands.  Money is only an idea.  If you want more money, simply change your thinking.  Money never starts an idea.  It is the idea that starts the money." With almost all data and information are available at our fingertips, we should seriously focus on generating ideas and provoking insights. By doing so, then we are in a better - also, faster and even smarter - position to make effective use of the constant bombardment of environmental data in order to produce valuable information, through our conceptual understanding and personal relevancy. And by seeing the pattern of relationships in the abundant information we produced, or "connecting the dots", as Steve Jobs so eloquently put it a decade ago, we get better ideas and insights. Putting our viable ideas and insights to work in our life, in our work, in our business, and/or even for our client(s), gives us the opportunity to know what works, what doesn't work and what could possibly work better, faster and smarter the next time around, with a little bit of tweaking on our part or acquisition of additional strategies and tactics. The gainful result is experience. Cumulative experience = knowledge, in the practical sense. As Albert Einstein is believed to have said: "Knowledge is experience; everything else is just information." Over time, with continual application and consistent evolution, our cumulative knowledge becomes expertise. Again, with ongoing adaptation, and continuous and never ending improvement in whatever we think and do, our discerning use of expertise eventually becomes wisdom. That's how I see the trajectory: DATA --> INFORMATION --> IDEAS ---> EXPERIENCE ---> KNOWLEDGE ---> EXPERTISE ---> WISDOM

1. Learn to separate your inner child from your logical mind Most people find this incredibly difficult at first, and laughably easy after some practice. Inner wisdom is something most children have. The logical mind is something most adults have. Inner wisdom is something that many logical adults squash in their young children, never knowing how important it is, and then those same children go on to become logical adults who squash their kids’ inner wisdom. It’s coming close to an epidemic in our part of the world. In order for us to reconnect with our inner guidance, we need to reconnect with our inner child. More often than not, our inner wisdom speaks to us by way of desire. Just like a bee is led to a flower by desire, so we are always being led towards our needs by deep, gut feelings. Children follow this kind of guidance without thinking twice. Their reasoning for doing things is “because it feels good,” “because it doesn’t feel right,” and other completely irrational reasons that make logical adults’ heads swim. Our logical mind guides us by way of analysis. Its optimal functioning is to find the most efficient ways to fulfill our needs. A mind that is united with the inner wisdom will become more and more efficient at fulfilling our deepest, most authentic desires. Without such guidance, however, the mind must find some other desires to fulfill, such as the desires of our parents, our peer groups, and, too often, the highest paying advertisers. The art of separating your inner child from your logical adult mind, then, is the art of separating your authentic desires from your conditioned ones. It is the fine art of knowing the difference between what you really, truly want and what you’ve been trained to want. 2. Make mental personalities for both On this journey, you will need to shift authority from your logical mind to your inner child. After some time, they will learn to work together, but at first, there will be a power struggle. The easiest way to know whom you’re speaking to is to give a real, human personality to both of them. When your mind begins to brew up anxiety and drawn out “What if…?!” stories, you’ll take it much less seriously if you imagine those words coming from an overworked and unappreciated office worker who hates her job and hasn’t slept properly in days. Likewise, when your inner guidance speaks to you in a soft whisper, you’ll follow it more faithfully if you imagine that you’re being beckoned by a wise 100-year-old man under a cherry blossom tree who speaks to you in riddles and never raises his voice. Even better, find real people in your life who represent these two factions within you. Your relationship to your logical mind – the pattern of you submitting to reason-based authority – might be perfectly reflected in your relationship with your boss, parent, or spouse. Likewise, your relationship to your inner guidance – the pattern of you ignoring its “childish” or “irrational” ideas – might be perfectly reflected in your relationship with your child, sibling, or grandparent. When you hear either voice speak to you, see its personality in your head. It will make it much easier for you to decide whom to trust. 3. Listen when your inner child speaks, don’t talk over it Imagine ignoring a person for 10, 20, 30 years and, then, when you need their help, showing up to their doorstep asking for favors. The chances of them jumping up enthusiastically are slim to none. If you have not been hearing your wise inner child, this is because you’ve ignored it for too long. You’ve instilled silence into a relationship that’s meant to be a lifetime conversation. It will take time to rebuild that trust. The good news is – your relationship with your inner child is never irreparably damaged. No matter how long it takes, your intuition will return to you. All you have to do is listen, with patience and presence, every time it speaks and not just when you need it to. Again, imagine your inner child as having a real, human personality. Each time you listen to that inner voice, acknowledge it, respect it, and do what it says, you will strengthen your relationship with it. Its voice will become louder with each conversation.  4. Realize that reprogramming your mind will take time, mistakes, and self-forgiveness When I began this journey, I would imagine my logical mind as a tiger – wild, powerful, and ferocious. Taming it, I got bloodied up many times. Reprogramming a lifetime of conditioning is difficult. It’s even more difficult to get your logic-loving brain to accept the notions of faith, love, and happiness. It will take time, no matter how hard you try. You will make mistakes. You will falter. Since there’s no way to avoid mistakes, you may as well learn to laugh at them. I can honestly say that learning the fine art of not taking myself so seriously has made more of a difference than anything else. No matter how long it takes or how many mistakes I make, I am doing my best, and that is enough.  5. Make self-discovery into a necessity You know that adage that tells you to accept the things you can’t change and change the ones you can? Well, the fact that self-discovery is essential for healing and happiness is something you can never change. No matter where in the world you go or what new people you’re around, you will always need to be your own best friend in order for your happiness to be sustainable. So, commit to that. Commit to discovering yourself and rekindling your relationship with your inner child with awed curiosity and ceaseless passion. You already commit to eating and sleeping each day, because you know you need those things to live. Accept your self-discovery as a basic need too. Make it a lifetime commitment. Go to the mirror, look in those striking eyes of yours, and say, “I promise to do my best to understand you, care for you, and listen to you, for as long as you shall live.” And I promise you that, if you explore yourself with the same curiosity as you would explore a new lover, you will not only find your sense of inner guidance, you’ll also find a deep happiness that is unshakable by chaos, criticism, or circumstance.
